Learn how to use CommandModule and Comma: Learn how to use CommandModule and CommandService for publishing and managing commands.
For complete CRUD implementation pattern: For complete CRUD implementation patterns using CommandService, see [Service Patterns](./service-patterns.md).
The `CommandService` is a core component: The `CommandService` is a core component of the framework that facilitates the management and synchronization of commands. It primarily provides methods for publishing both full commands and partial commands, allowing for their processing either synchronously or asynchronously, thereby enhancing the overall efficiency and flexibility of command handling within the system.
The `CommandModule` is a dynamic module: The `CommandModule` is a dynamic module used to register data sync handlers and provide services associated with a table name. When importing this module, you must provide a specific option for use.
If set to `true`, it will skip errors fr: If set to `true`, it will skip errors from previous commands
If set to `true`, it will reset default: If set to `true`, it will reset default data sync handlers
Here, the `CommandModule` registers with: Here, the `CommandModule` registers with the `cat` table name and provides the `CatDataSyncRdsHandler` to the data sync handlers.
In the example for the method below, ass: In the example for the method below, assume you import the `CommandModule` into your module as follows:
Then, the `CommandService` and `DataServ: Then, the `CommandService` and `DataService` will be ready for injection into other services for your use.
Utilize this method to publish a full co: Utilize this method to publish a full command, as it will insert the command data into the **command** table.
The method provides immediate feedback b: The method provides immediate feedback by returning the command data right away, allowing you to proceed without waiting for the command to be processed. Subsequently, the command is handled asynchronously in the background, ensuring that your application remains responsive while the processing occurs.
For example, you can publish a new cat c: For example, you can publish a new cat command as bellow:
This method allows you to create new com: This method allows you to create new command data based on the previous command with the same `pk` and `sk` (primary key) values.
As same as the `publishAsync` method, th: As same as the `publishAsync` method, the method immediately returns the updated command data without waiting for the command to be processed.
For example, you want to update cat's na: For example, you want to update cat's name:
This method serves as a synchronous coun: This method serves as a synchronous counterpart to the `publishAsync` method, meaning that it will halt the execution of the code until the command has been fully processed. This ensures that you receive the result of the command before proceeding with any further operations in your code.
This method is a synchronous version of: This method is a synchronous version of the `publishPartialUpdateAsync` method. It will block the execution of the code until the command is processed.

The method returns the command data.
*async* `publishPartialUpdate( input: Co: *async* `publishPartialUpdate( input: CommandPartialInputModel, options: ICommandOptions)` deprecated
Deprecated, for removal: This API elemen: Deprecated, for removal: This API element is subject to removal in a future version. Use [`publishPartialUpdateAsync` method](#async-publishpartialupdateasync-input-commandpartialinputmodel-options-icommandoptions) instead.
This method allows you to create new com: This method allows you to create new command data based on the previous command.
The method returns the updated command d: The method returns the updated command data.
If you want to reapply the data sync han: If you want to reapply the data sync handler, this method is designed for you to use. You only need to call the function as follows:
Retrieves a command item by its primary: Retrieves a command item by its primary key. If the sort key does not include a version separator, it automatically calls `getLatestItem` to get the latest version.
Get a specific version of a command: Get a specific version of a command
If no version in sk, automatically gets: If no version in sk, automatically gets latest version
Retrieves the latest version of a comman: Retrieves the latest version of a command item by its primary key. This method uses a lookup algorithm that starts from the data table's version and searches up/down to find the most recent command version.
Retrieves the next version of a command: Retrieves the next version of a command based on the current command's key. This is useful for processing command chains or implementing retry logic.
Returns command with sk: \"CAT#cat001#00: Returns command with sk: "CAT#cat001#00000003" if exists
*async* `updateStatus(key: DetailKey, st: *async* `updateStatus(key: DetailKey, status: string, notifyId?: string): Promise<void>`
Updates the status of a command and send: Updates the status of a command and sends an SNS notification. This is commonly used to update task or process statuses and notify subscribers of the change.
Update status and send SNS notification: Update status and send SNS notification
Creates a duplicate of an existing comma: Creates a duplicate of an existing command with an incremented version number. The duplicated command will have `source` set to `"duplicated"` and updated metadata (timestamp, user, IP).
Stores an AWS Step Functions task token: Stores an AWS Step Functions task token on a command item. This is used when integrating with Step Functions to enable callback patterns.
Store the Step Functions task token: Store the Step Functions task token
Later, use the token to send task succes: Later, use the token to send task success/failure
Updates the TTL (Time To Live) of the pr: Updates the TTL (Time To Live) of the previous version of a command. This is typically used internally to manage command history retention. Returns `null` if the version is too low or the previous command doesn't exist.
This method is primarily used internally: This method is primarily used internally by the framework for command history management. Direct usage is rarely needed in application code.
Returns the array of registered data syn: Returns the array of registered data sync handlers for this CommandService instance. This is useful when you need to inspect or iterate over the handlers programmatically.
Get all registered data sync handlers: Get all registered data sync handlers
Retrieves a specific data sync handler b: Retrieves a specific data sync handler by its class name. Returns `undefined` if no handler with the specified name is found.
Get a specific handler by name: Get a specific handler by name
